chapter.subject: Chemistry
chapter.chapter_name: Practical Chemistry (Recognition & Identification of Gases, Action of Heat, Hard & Soft Water, Water Pollution)

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct definition for hydrogen gas based on its laboratory identification?

options.label: A
options.text: A colourless, odourless gas that turns lime water milky.

options.label: B
options.text: A colourless, odourless gas that burns with a pale blue flame and produces a pop sound with air.

options.label: C
options.text: A greenish-yellow gas with a pungent odour that bleaches litmus.

options.label: D
options.text: A colourless gas with a rotten egg smell that turns lead acetate paper black.

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen gas is colourless, odourless, burns with a pale blue flame, and produces a characteristic 'pop' sound when ignited in air.

questions.question_text: A colourless, odourless gas is evolved when dilute sulphuric acid is added to zinc granules. The gas burns with a 'pop' sound. Which gas is it?

options.label: A
options.text: Carbon dioxide

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen

options.label: D
options.text: Ammonia

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen is prepared by the action of dilute acids on metals above hydrogen in the activity series (e.g., Zn, Mg, Fe). The 'pop' sound test is unique to hydrogen.

questions.question_text: A student tests a colourless, odourless gas with a burning splint. The splint extinguishes. The student concludes it is hydrogen. Why is this conclusion incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrogen always rekindles a glowing splint.

options.label: B
options.text: The 'pop' sound test is necessary; a burning splint extinguishing is not a test for hydrogen.

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen is acidic and would have turned blue litmus red first.

options.label: D
options.text: The gas must have been impure; pure hydrogen would have burned.

questions.key_concept: A burning splint is brought near hydrogen to hear the 'pop' sound (for a mixture with air) or see it burn (if pure). A splint extinguishing is a test for non-supporter gases like CO2, not a positive test for H2.

questions.question_text: Which of the following reactions CANNOT be used to prepare hydrogen gas in the laboratory?

options.label: A
options.text: Zn + 2HCl -> ZnCl2 + H2

options.label: B
options.text: Mg + H2SO4(dil) -> MgSO4 + H2

options.label: C
options.text: Cu + 2HCl -> CuCl2 + H2

options.label: D
options.text: Fe + 2HCl -> FeCl2 + H2

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen is prepared by the action of dilute acids on metals ABOVE hydrogen in the reactivity series. Copper is below hydrogen and does not displace it from acids.

questions.question_text: How can you distinguish between hydrogen and oxygen gas using a single chemical test?

options.label: A
options.text: Pass both gases through lime water; one turns it milky.

options.label: B
options.text: Bring a glowing wooden splinter near each; oxygen rekindles it, hydrogen gives a pop sound.

options.label: C
options.text: Test with moist litmus paper; one is acidic, the other is basic.

options.label: D
options.text: Bring a burning splinter near each; both support combustion equally.

questions.key_concept: Oxygen supports combustion (rekindles glowing splinter). Hydrogen, when mixed with air, burns with a 'pop' sound. This is a key distinguishing test.

questions.question_text: Why is the 'pop' sound test for hydrogen performed with a burning splinter and not a glowing splinter?

options.label: A
options.text: A glowing splinter is not hot enough to ignite the hydrogen-air mixture.

options.label: B
options.text: The test requires an open flame to ignite the hydrogen, which then burns rapidly in air producing the sound.

options.label: C
options.text: A glowing splinter would be extinguished by hydrogen, giving a false negative.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen itself glows, so a glowing splinter would not be visible.

questions.key_concept: The 'pop' sound is due to the rapid combustion of hydrogen when an ignition source (burning splinter) is provided. A glowing splinter tests for oxygen, not hydrogen.

questions.question_text: What is the key identifying property of oxygen gas?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a supporter of combustion.

options.label: B
options.text: It is acidic in nature.

options.label: C
options.text: It has a pungent smell.

options.label: D
options.text: It turns lime water milky.

questions.key_concept: Oxygen is a colourless, odourless, neutral gas that supports combustion. It rekindles a glowing splinter.

questions.question_text: A gas is collected from the heating of mercuric oxide. When a glowing wooden splinter is inserted into the gas jar, it bursts into flames. The gas is:

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrogen

options.label: B
options.text: Carbon dioxide

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen

options.label: D
options.text: Nitrogen dioxide

questions.key_concept: The gas that rekindles a glowing splinter is oxygen. It is prepared by heating certain metallic oxides like HgO, Pb3O4.

questions.question_text: A student states that oxygen gas can be identified because it turns alkaline pyrogallol solution colourless. What is the error?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxygen turns pyrogallol dark brown, not colourless.

options.label: B
options.text: Pyrogallol is used for carbon dioxide, not oxygen.

options.label: C
options.text: The test requires acidified pyrogallol.

options.label: D
options.text: Oxygen bleaches pyrogallol.

questions.key_concept: Oxygen is absorbed by colourless alkaline pyrogallol, turning it dark brown. 'Colourless' is incorrect.

questions.question_text: Which substance, on heating, will produce oxygen gas?

options.label: A
options.text: Copper carbonate

options.label: B
options.text: Lead nitrate

options.label: C
options.text: Red lead (Pb3O4)

options.label: D
options.text: Ammonium chloride

questions.key_concept: Heavy metallic oxides like Pb3O4, PbO2, and HgO decompose on heating to give oxygen.

questions.question_text: Both hydrogen and oxygen are colourless and odourless. Which test gives a positive result for oxygen but not for hydrogen?

options.label: A
options.text: Burning splint produces a pop sound.

options.label: B
options.text: Glowing splinter rekindles.

options.label: C
options.text: Turns lime water milky.

options.label: D
options.text: Turns moist blue litmus red.

questions.key_concept: The glowing splinter test is unique to oxygen. Hydrogen does not rekindle a glowing splinter.

questions.question_text: Why is a glowing splinter used to test for oxygen instead of a burning splinter?

options.label: A
options.text: A burning splinter would add its own flame, masking the effect.

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen supports combustion; a glowing ember, which is still combustible, will burst into flame in its presence.

options.label: C
options.text: A burning splinter produces carbon dioxide which interferes with the test.

options.label: D
options.text: Oxygen extinguishes a burning splinter.

questions.key_concept: A glowing splinter has combustible material (carbon) at a high temperature. In the presence of oxygen, it reignites, providing a clear visual test.

questions.question_text: Which statement correctly defines a key test for carbon dioxide?

options.label: A
options.text: It turns lime water milky, and the milkiness disappears in excess.

options.label: B
options.text: It turns lime water milky, and the milkiness persists in excess.

options.label: C
options.text: It turns lime water green.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on lime water.

questions.key_concept: Carbon dioxide turns lime water (calcium hydroxide) milky due to insoluble calcium carbonate. Excess CO2 forms soluble calcium bicarbonate, clearing the milkiness.

questions.question_text: A colourless, odourless gas is produced when dilute hydrochloric acid is added to marble chips (CaCO3). The gas turns lime water milky. The gas is:

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrogen

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen

options.label: C
options.text: Carbon dioxide

options.label: D
options.text: Chlorine

questions.key_concept: Carbon dioxide is produced by the action of dilute acids on carbonates. The lime water test is confirmatory.

questions.question_text: A student says carbon dioxide can be identified because it turns moist blue litmus paper blue. What is wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: CO2 turns moist blue litmus faint red, as it forms carbonic acid.

options.label: B
options.text: CO2 has no effect on litmus paper.

options.label: C
options.text: CO2 turns litmus paper blue only when dry.

options.label: D
options.text: CO2 bleaches litmus paper.

questions.key_concept: Carbon dioxide dissolves in water to form carbonic acid (H2CO3), which is weakly acidic and turns blue litmus faint red.

questions.question_text: Which of the following will NOT produce carbon dioxide on strong heating?

options.label: A
options.text: Zinc carbonate

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium carbonate

options.label: C
options.text: Copper carbonate

options.label: D
options.text: Calcium carbonate

questions.key_concept: Sodium carbonate and potassium carbonate are stable and do not decompose on heating to give CO2. Most other metallic carbonates decompose.

questions.question_text: Both carbon dioxide and sulphur dioxide turn lime water milky initially. How can they be distinguished?

options.label: A
options.text: By smell: SO2 has a pungent smell, CO2 is odourless.

options.label: B
options.text: By using acidified K2Cr2O7 paper: SO2 turns it green, CO2 has no effect.

options.label: C
options.text: By the pop sound test.

options.label: D
options.text: By testing with glowing splinter.

questions.key_concept: SO2 is a reducing agent and decolorizes KMnO4 or turns K2Cr2O7 green. CO2 has no such effect. This is a key distinguishing test.

questions.question_text: Why does the milkiness disappear when excess carbon dioxide is passed through lime water?

options.label: A
options.text: The calcium carbonate precipitate evaporates.

options.label: B
options.text: The calcium carbonate reacts with excess CO2 to form soluble calcium hydrogencarbonate.

options.label: C
options.text: The carbon dioxide bleaches the white precipitate.

options.label: D
options.text: The solution becomes too acidic and dissolves the precipitate.

questions.key_concept: CaCO3 (insoluble, milky) + CO2 + H2O -> Ca(HCO3)2 (soluble, clear). This property is unique to CO2 among common acidic gases.

concepts.concept_name: Action of Heat on Salts - Carbonates and Bicarbonates

questions.question_text: What is the general observation when most metallic carbonates (except Na2CO3, K2CO3) are heated strongly?

options.label: A
options.text: They sublime without a residue.

options.label: B
options.text: They decompose to give the metal oxide and carbon dioxide gas.

options.label: C
options.text: They melt and give off oxygen gas.

options.label: D
options.text: They give off ammonia gas.

questions.key_concept: General equation: Metal Carbonate -> (heat) -> Metal Oxide + Carbon Dioxide.

questions.question_text: A light green powder turns black on strong heating and gives off a gas that turns lime water milky. The original substance is most likely:

options.label: A
options.text: Copper nitrate

options.label: B
options.text: Copper carbonate

options.label: C
options.text: Zinc carbonate

options.label: D
options.text: Lead carbonate

questions.key_concept: Copper carbonate (green) decomposes to black copper oxide and carbon dioxide (turns lime water milky).

questions.question_text: A student heats a white powder. It turns yellow when hot and white when cold, and gives off CO2. He concludes it is zinc oxide. What is the mistake?

options.label: A
options.text: Zinc oxide is the product (residue), not the original substance being heated.

options.label: B
options.text: Zinc oxide does not change colour on heating.

options.label: C
options.text: The gas evolved should be oxygen, not CO2.

options.label: D
options.text: The original substance should have been blue.

questions.key_concept: The student identified the residue (ZnO). The original substance was zinc carbonate, which on heating gives ZnO (yellow hot, white cold) and CO2.

questions.question_text: Which pair of substances will BOTH give off carbon dioxide gas when heated?

options.label: A
options.text: Zinc carbonate and Sodium carbonate

options.label: B
options.text: Copper carbonate and Zinc carbonate

options.label: C
options.text: Ammonium chloride and Iodine

options.label: D
options.text: Lead nitrate and Copper nitrate

questions.key_concept: Both ZnCO3 and CuCO3 decompose on heating to give metal oxide and CO2. Na2CO3 is stable.

questions.question_text: How would you distinguish between samples of copper carbonate and copper nitrate by heating them in a dry test tube?

options.label: A
options.text: Both give black residue, but only carbonate gives a gas turning lime water milky.

options.label: B
options.text: Carbonate gives only CO2 (colourless). Nitrate gives reddish-brown NO2 and may give oxygen.

options.label: C
options.text: Carbonate sublimes, nitrate decomposes.

options.label: D
options.text: Nitrate gives water vapour, carbonate does not.

questions.key_concept: CuCO3 -> CuO (black) + CO2 (colourless, turns lime water milky). Cu(NO3)2 -> CuO (black) + NO2 (brown) + O2. The colour of the gas is key.

questions.question_text: Why does washing soda (Na2CO3.10H2O) give off water vapour on heating, but not carbon dioxide, while copper carbonate gives off CO2?

options.label: A
options.text: Washing soda loses water of crystallization first; its anhydrous form (Na2CO3) is stable and does not decompose like other carbonates.

options.label: B
options.text: Washing soda contains less carbon than copper carbonate.

options.label: C
options.text: The heat provided is insufficient to decompose sodium carbonate.

options.label: D
options.text: Copper carbonate is a basic carbonate, while washing soda is a normal carbonate.

questions.key_concept: Sodium and potassium carbonates do not decompose on heating. They only lose water of crystallization if hydrated. Most other metallic carbonates decompose to oxide and CO2.

concepts.concept_name: Action of Heat on Salts - Nitrates

questions.question_text: What is the common product gas (besides oxygen) when heavy metal nitrates like lead nitrate or copper nitrate are heated?

options.label: A
options.text: Nitrogen

options.label: B
options.text: Nitrogen dioxide

options.label: C
options.text: Ammonia

options.label: D
options.text: Nitrous oxide

questions.key_concept: Nitrates of heavy metals (Pb, Cu, Zn) decompose on heating to give the metal oxide, nitrogen dioxide (brown gas), and oxygen.

questions.question_text: A white crystalline solid on strong heating gives a cracking sound, a reddish-brown gas, and a yellow residue when hot which turns white on cooling. The solid is:

options.label: A
options.text: Zinc nitrate

options.label: B
options.text: Lead nitrate

options.label: C
options.text: Ammonium chloride

options.label: D
options.text: Copper carbonate

questions.key_concept: Lead nitrate decomposes with a cracking sound, gives brown NO2, and leaves yellow PbO (hot) which turns white (cool).

questions.question_text: A student heats sodium nitrate expecting to see brown fumes of nitrogen dioxide. Why won't this happen?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium nitrate decomposes to give sodium nitrite and oxygen; it does not produce NO2.

options.label: B
options.text: The heat provided is insufficient.

options.label: C
options.text: Sodium nitrate is not a heavy metal nitrate.

options.label: D
options.text: The NO2 produced is colourless in this case.

questions.key_concept: Nitrates of sodium and potassium decompose differently, giving the nitrite and oxygen. NO2 is characteristic of heavy metal nitrates.

questions.question_text: Which observation is correct when copper nitrate crystals are heated?

options.label: A
options.text: Blue crystals -> White anhydrous salt -> Black residue, with steamy vapours and brown gas.

options.label: B
options.text: White crystals -> Yellow residue (hot) -> White residue (cold), with colourless gas.

options.label: C
options.text: Orange crystals -> Green residue, with nitrogen gas.

options.label: D
options.text: Violet crystals sublime.

questions.key_concept: Hydrated copper nitrate (blue) first loses water (steamy vapours, white Cu(NO3)2), then decomposes to black CuO, brown NO2, and O2.

questions.question_text: How can you distinguish between zinc nitrate and ammonium chloride by heating?

options.label: A
options.text: Zinc nitrate leaves a residue, ammonium chloride sublimes completely.

options.label: B
options.text: Both give white fumes.

options.label: C
options.text: Zinc nitrate gives a pop sound, ammonium chloride does not.

options.label: D
options.text: Ammonium chloride gives a brown gas.

questions.key_concept: Zinc nitrate decomposes to leave a solid residue (ZnO). Ammonium chloride sublimes, leaving no residue. This is a fundamental difference.

questions.question_text: Why does a glowing splinter burst into flame when introduced into the gas mixture from heated lead nitrate, even though one gas (NO2) is acidic and non-supporter?

options.label: A
options.text: The mixture contains oxygen gas, which supports combustion and overrides the effect of NO2.

options.label: B
options.text: NO2 itself is a supporter of combustion.

options.label: C
options.text: The heat from the glowing splinter decomposes NO2 into nitrogen and oxygen.

options.label: D
options.text: The glowing splinter test is not reliable in the presence of other gases.

questions.key_concept: Lead nitrate decomposition produces both NO2 and O2. The presence of oxygen (a supporter) causes the glowing splinter to reignite.

questions.question_text: What is the defining characteristic of soft water?

options.label: A
options.text: It contains chlorides of calcium and magnesium.

options.label: B
options.text: It forms lather easily with ordinary soap.

options.label: C
options.text: It contains bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not form lather with any soap.

questions.key_concept: Soft water is free from dissolved salts of calcium and magnesium, so it readily forms lather with soap.

questions.question_text: When ordinary soap is rubbed in two water samples, sample A forms lather easily while sample B forms a scum. Identify the samples.

options.label: A
options.text: A is soft water, B is hard water.

options.label: B
options.text: A is temporary hard water, B is permanent hard water.

options.label: C
options.text: A is hard water, B is soft water.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are different types of hard water.

questions.key_concept: Soft water lathers easily. Hard water reacts with soap to form insoluble calcium/magnesium stearate (scum), wasting soap.

questions.question_text: A student says that boiling can remove permanent hardness caused by calcium sulphate. Why is this incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Boiling only removes temporary hardness caused by bicarbonates. Sulphates require chemical treatment like washing soda.

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium sulphate evaporates on boiling.

options.label: C
options.text: Boiling makes permanent hardness worse.

options.label: D
options.text: Permanent hardness is caused by chlorides, not sulphates.

questions.key_concept: Temporary hardness is due to bicarbonates, removed by boiling. Permanent hardness is due to chlorides/sulphates, not removed by boiling.

questions.question_text: Which method can soften both temporary and permanent hard water?

options.label: A
options.text: Boiling

options.label: B
options.text: Adding washing soda (Na2CO3)

options.label: C
options.text: Using soap

options.label: D
options.text: Filtration without treatment

questions.key_concept: Washing soda precipitates calcium/magnesium ions as carbonates (from bicarbonates) or as carbonates (from chlorides/sulphates), removing both types of hardness.

questions.question_text: How can you experimentally distinguish between temporary hard water and permanent hard water?

options.label: A
options.text: Boil equal volumes, then filter and test with soap. The one that now lathers easily was temporary hard water.

options.label: B
options.text: Test both with soap without any treatment; both will behave identically.

options.label: C
options.text: Add washing soda to both; only temporary hard water will show a precipitate.

options.label: D
options.text: Test pH; temporary hard water is acidic, permanent is basic.

questions.key_concept: Boiling removes temporary hardness (precipitates carbonates) but not permanent hardness. The soap test after boiling and filtration distinguishes them.

questions.question_text: Why do detergents lather with hard water while ordinary soaps do not?

options.label: A
options.text: Calcium and magnesium salts of detergents are soluble in water, so they do not form scum.

options.label: B
options.text: Detergents are stronger acids that dissolve the hardness salts.

options.label: C
options.text: Soaps contain -COOH group, detergents do not, which prevents reaction with Ca2+ ions.

options.label: D
options.text: Detergents contain bleaching agents that remove hardness.

questions.key_concept: Soap anions (stearate) form insoluble precipitates (scum) with Ca2+/Mg2+. Detergent anions (sulphonate) form soluble salts, thus lathering even in hard water.

questions.question_text: What does a high Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD) indicate about a water body?

options.label: A
options.text: The water is very clean and pure.

options.label: B
options.text: There is a high level of organic pollution, leading to more oxygen consumption by microbes.

options.label: C
options.text: The water has a high concentration of dissolved oxygen.

options.label: D
options.text: The water is highly acidic.

questions.key_concept: BOD measures oxygen used by microorganisms to decompose organic waste. High BOD = high organic pollution = low dissolved oxygen for aquatic life.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a physical indicator of water pollution?

options.label: A
options.text: Foul smell

options.label: B
options.text: pH of 7

options.label: C
options.text: Low BOD

options.label: D
options.text: High dissolved oxygen

questions.key_concept: Foul smell, bad taste, oil/grease on surface, and excessive algae are direct physical/ sensory indicators of pollution.

questions.question_text: A student measures the pH of a lake water sample as 6.5 and concludes it is heavily polluted. Is this conclusion necessarily correct?

options.label: A
options.text: No, pH alone is not conclusive. Slight acidity can be natural. Other parameters (BOD, turbidity) must be checked.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, any pH below 7 indicates severe pollution.

options.label: C
options.text: No, polluted water is always basic, not acidic.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, pure water has a pH of exactly 7.

questions.key_concept: While a pH far from 7 (e.g., <4 or >9) indicates pollution, a slight deviation (6.5-8.5) can be normal. Pollution assessment requires multiple parameters.

questions.question_text: Which activity is a source of thermal pollution?

options.label: A
options.text: Discharge of hot water from industrial cooling towers into rivers.

options.label: B
options.text: Use of detergents for washing clothes.

options.label: C
options.text: Run-off from agricultural fields containing fertilizers.

options.label: D
options.text: Oil spills from tankers.

questions.key_concept: Thermal pollution is the harmful increase in water temperature, often from industrial coolant discharge, which reduces dissolved oxygen.

questions.question_text: How does pollution from sewage (organic waste) differ from pollution from industrial acids in its effect on dissolved oxygen (DO)?

options.label: A
options.text: Sewage increases BOD, lowering DO. Industrial acids may kill organisms but don't necessarily affect DO directly via BOD.

options.label: B
options.text: Both increase DO levels.

options.label: C
options.text: Sewage has no effect on DO, industrial acids increase DO.

options.label: D
options.text: Both decrease DO by the same mechanism.

questions.key_concept: Organic pollution (sewage) is decomposed by bacteria, which consume oxygen (high BOD, low DO). Chemical pollution (acids) may be toxic but doesn't always involve microbial oxygen consumption.

questions.question_text: Why is water with high turbidity considered polluted?

options.label: A
options.text: Suspended particles block sunlight, reduce photosynthesis in aquatic plants, and can clog respiratory systems of animals.

options.label: B
options.text: Turbidity directly increases the pH of water making it toxic.

options.label: C
options.text: Turbid water always has low hardness.

options.label: D
options.text: It indicates a high concentration of dissolved salts.

questions.key_concept: Turbidity reduces light penetration, affecting aquatic plant life and oxygen production. It also physically harms aquatic organisms.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the flame test in practical chemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the acidic radical present in a salt.

options.label: B
options.text: To identify the metallic ion (cation) present in a salt based on the colour imparted to a flame.

options.label: C
options.text: To test the pH of a solution.

options.label: D
options.text: To determine the water of crystallization in a salt.

questions.key_concept: The flame test is a qualitative analytical technique used to detect the presence of certain metal ions (e.g., Na+, K+, Ca2+, Cu2+) based on their characteristic flame colours.

questions.question_text: A salt imparts a persistent golden yellow colour to the Bunsen flame. The cation present is likely:

options.label: A
options.text: Potassium

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium

options.label: D
options.text: Copper

questions.key_concept: Sodium salts give a persistent golden yellow flame.

questions.question_text: A student performs a flame test on a salt and observes a lilac flame. When viewed through a blue glass, the flame appears pink. He concludes it is sodium. What is the error?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium's yellow flame is masked/blocked by blue glass. Lilac flame seen through blue glass as pink is characteristic of potassium.

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium flame is always violet, not lilac.

options.label: C
options.text: The blue glass test is used for calcium, not sodium or potassium.

options.label: D
options.text: The student should have used a red glass.

questions.key_concept: Blue glass absorbs yellow light. It is used to mask the strong yellow of sodium to see the violet/pink of potassium.

questions.question_text: Which sequence of steps is CORRECT for performing a flame test?

options.label: A
options.text: Clean Pt wire with conc. HCl -> Heat in flame until colourless -> Dip in acid and sample -> Introduce into flame.

options.label: B
options.text: Dip Pt wire in sample -> Heat in flame -> Observe colour immediately.

options.label: C
options.text: Heat Pt wire -> Dip in water -> Dip in sample -> Heat again.

options.label: D
options.text: Use any wire, dip in sample, and put in the luminous flame.

questions.key_concept: The platinum wire must be thoroughly cleaned to remove impurities that could give false colours. The non-luminous (roaring) flame is used for clear observation.

questions.question_text: How can you distinguish between sodium chloride and calcium chloride using only a flame test and a blue glass?

options.label: A
options.text: Without glass: Na gives golden yellow, Ca gives brick red. With blue glass: Na flame vanishes/appears colourless, Ca flame appears greenish.

options.label: B
options.text: Both give the same colour without glass, but differ with glass.

options.label: C
options.text: Sodium flame is violet through blue glass, calcium flame is yellow.

options.label: D
options.text: Blue glass is only used for potassium, not for these.

questions.key_concept: Sodium (yellow) and Calcium (brick red) have distinct colours. Blue glass masks yellow (sodium appears faint/colourless) but allows the calcium greenish hue to be seen.

questions.question_text: Why is a platinum or nichrome wire used in the flame test and not a copper or iron wire?

options.label: A
options.text: Platinum/nichrome is inert and does not impart its own colour to the flame, avoiding interference.

options.label: B
options.text: Copper and iron wires are not good conductors of heat.

options.label: C
options.text: Platinum wire is cheaper than copper wire.

options.label: D
options.text: Copper wire would melt in the Bunsen flame.

questions.key_concept: The wire material must not produce a characteristic flame colour that masks the sample's colour. Platinum is ideal due to its high melting point and inertness.
